citeinfo.title: Predicted existing salt marsh losses in 2100 under a 1m sea leavel rise scenario in Corpus Christi Bay, Texas.

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

pubinfo.pubplace: 205 N. Carizzo Street, Corpus Christi, TX, 78401, US

citeinfo.title: Informing conservation and resiliency planning using sea-level rise and storm-surge scenario impact estimates in Corpus Christi Bay

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

descript.abstract: This dataset shows the percentage of loss of existing salt marsh (irregularly flooded and regularly flooded) by 2100 under a 1 meter SLR scenario. SLAMM was used to predict the future distribution of marshes and the marsh loss calculations were summarized by each individual marsh polygon (includes all marsh areas > 2500 sq meters).
descript.purpose: This file was created for The Nature Conservancy's Sea Level Rise Project for the northern Gulf of Mexico with funding from the Coastal Bend Bays and Estuary Program (CBBEP). This dataset shows the percentage of loss of existing salt marshes (irregularly flooded and regularly flooded) in Corpus Christi Bay, Texas by 2100 under a 1 m sea level rise scenario. The map represents the footprint of all salt marsh areas (> 2500 sq. meters), which were derived from predicted landcover maps of Corpus Christi Bay, Texas. The landcover maps used for the study area were derived from Sea Level Rise Affecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) using the 1m of sea-level rise by 2100 scenario which predict how marshes might migrate inland due to increasing sea levels.

procstep.procdesc: TNC Conservation and Resiliency analyses were created from SLAMM and ADCIRC modeling outputs for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas (see reports at www.SLRportal.org)
